Water Act 2014
2014 CHAPTER 21

An Act to make provision about the water industry; about compensation formodification of licences to abstract water; about main river maps; aboutrecords of waterworks; for the regulation of the water environment; about theprovision of flood insurance for household premises; about internal drainageboards; about Regional Flood and Coastal Committees; and for connectedpurposes.

Be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the adviceand consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this presentParliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—
Part 1Water industry
CHAPTER 1Water supply licences and sewerage licences
Expansion of water supply licensing
Types of water supply licence and arrangements with water undertakers
For section 17A of the Water Industry Act 1991 there is substituted—
“17AWater supply licences
The Authority may grant to a person a licence in respect of the use of thesupply system of a water undertaker (a “water supply licence”).
A water supply licence may give the holder of the licence one or more ofthe following authorisations and combination of authorisations—
a retail authorisation;
a wholesale authorisation;
a restricted retail authorisation;
a restricted retail authorisation and a supplementary authorisation.
Schedule 2A makes provision as to the authorisations (including theiroperation in England and Wales).
In the case of each of the authorisations, an authorisation to do a thingis an authorisation to do it in accordance with Chapter 2A of Part 3.
The Authority may exercise the power to grant a water supply licence onlyin accordance with a general authorisation given by the Secretary of State.
Before giving a general authorisation as regards the Authority, theSecretary of State must consult the Welsh Ministers.
References in this Act to a water supply licensee are references to aperson that is the holder for the time being of a water supply licence.
AAWater supply licences: restrictions on grants
Before the Authority grants a water supply licence giving a wholesaleauthorisation, it must consult—
the Secretary of State;
the Chief Inspector of Drinking Water;
the Environment Agency;
the NRBW.
Before the Authority grants a water supply licence giving a supplementaryauthorisation, it must consult—
the Secretary of State;
the Chief Inspector of Drinking Water;
the Environment Agency;
the Welsh Ministers;
the Chief Inspector of Drinking Water for Wales if there is one;
the NRBW.
A water supply licence may not be granted to a water undertaker.
A water supply licence may not be granted to a person unless that person isa limited company.
The restriction in subsection (4) does not apply if the water supplylicence gives only—
a retail authorisation,
a restricted retail authorisation, or
a retail authorisation and a restricted retail authorisation.”
After Schedule 2 to the Water Industry Act 1991 there is inserted theSchedule set out in Schedule 1.
Schedule 2 (which amends Chapter 2A of Part 3 of the Water Industry Act1991 which relates to water undertakers’ duties to enable operations of watersupply licensees) has effect.
The supply system of a water undertaker
Section 17B of the Water Industry Act 1991 (guidance and interpretation) isamended as follows.
After subsection (4) there is inserted—

“(4A)In this Chapter, references to the supply system of a water undertakerare, in the case of an undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in England,references to the system comprising the following—
any reservoirs and other places of storage and any treatment worksdeveloped or maintained by the water undertaker for the purpose of complyingwith its duty under section 37, and
any water mains and other pipes which it is the water undertaker’s duty todevelop and maintain by virtue of section 37.”

In subsection (5) (interpretation of references to the supply system of awater undertaker), after “undertaker are” there is inserted “, in the case ofan undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in Wales,”.
The threshold requirement

The Secretary of State may by order made by statutory instrument repealsection 17A(3)(b) of the Water Industry Act 1991 (the threshold requirementaffecting premises in England and Wales), so far as it relates to premisessupplied using the supply system of a water undertaker whose area is wholly ormainly in England.

The Welsh Ministers may by order made by statutory instrument repealsection 17A(3)(b) of the Water Industry Act 1991, so far as it relates topremises supplied using the supply system of a water undertaker whose area iswholly or mainly in Wales.
The references in subsections (1) and (2) to section 17A of the WaterIndustry Act 1991 are to the section 17A that is to be repealed (bysubstitution) by section 1 of this Act.
The Welsh Ministers may by order made by statutory instrument repealparagraph 7(b) of Schedule 2A to the Water Industry Act 1991 (inserted bySchedule 1 to this Act).
An order under subsection (1), (2) or (4) may make such amendments of theWater Industry Act 1991 and this Act as are necessary or appropriate inconsequence of the repeal made by the order.

A statutory instrument containing an order to be made by the Secretary ofState under subsection (1) may not be made unless a draft of the instrumenthas been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House ofParliament.

A statutory instrument containing an order to be made by the WelshMinisters under subsection (2) or (4) may not be made unless a draft of theinstrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, the NationalAssembly for Wales.
Introduction of sewerage licences
Types of sewerage licence and arrangements with sewerage undertakers
After section 17B of the Water Industry Act 1991 there is inserted—
“17BASewerage licences
The Authority may grant to a person a licence in respect of the use of thesewerage system of a sewerage undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly inEngland (a “sewerage licence”).
A sewerage licence may give the holder of the licence one or more of thefollowing—
a retail authorisation;
a wholesale authorisation;
a disposal authorisation.
Schedule 2B makes provision as to the authorisations.
In the case of each of the authorisations, an authorisation to do a thingis an authorisation to do it in accordance with Chapter 2A of Part 4.
The Authority may exercise the power to grant a sewerage licence only inaccordance with a general authorisation given by the Secretary of State.
References in this Act to a sewerage licensee are references to a personthat is the holder for the time being of a sewerage licence.
References in this Chapter to the sewerage system of a sewerage undertakerare references to the system comprising—

the system of public sewers, the facilities for emptying public sewers andthe sewage disposal works and other facilities for dealing effectually withthe contents of public sewers that the undertaker is required to provide bysection 94, and
the lateral drains that the undertaker is required to maintain by section94.
BBSewerage licences: restrictions on grants
The Authority must consult the Secretary of State, the Environment Agencyand the NRBW before granting a licence that gives—
a wholesale authorisation, or
a disposal authorisation.
A sewerage licence granted to a sewerage undertaker may not give theholder—
a retail authorisation, or
a wholesale authorisation.
A sewerage licence may not be granted to a person unless that person is alimited company.
The restriction in subsection (3) does not apply if the sewerage licencegives only a retail authorisation.”
After Schedule 2A to the Water Industry Act 1991 (inserted by section 1)there is inserted the Schedule set out in Schedule 3.
Schedule 4 (which amends Part 4 of the Water Industry Act 1991 to add aChapter 2A relating to arrangements between sewerage undertakers and seweragelicensees) has effect.
Application as regards Wales
Water supply and sewerage licensing changes applied as regards Wales
Schedule 5 (which contains amendments in connection with applying licensingchanges to relation to relevant undertakers whose areas are wholly or mainlyin Wales) has effect.
Licensing arrangements between England and Wales and Scotland
Arrangements with the Water Industry Commission for Scotland
The Water Industry Act 1991 is amended as follows.
After section 17F (procedure for granting and varying licences) there isinserted—
“17FAApplications forwarded by the Water Industry Commission forScotland
The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about—

treating a 2005 Act application for the grant of a water services licenceunder section 6 of the 2005 Act as being also an application under section 17Ffor the grant of a water supply licence giving only a retail authorisation ora restricted retail authorisation or both;

treating a 2005 Act application for the grant of a sewerage serviceslicence under section 6 of the 2005 Act as being also an application undersection 17F for the grant of a sewerage licence giving only a retailauthorisation.
The regulations may in particular make provision about—

the circumstances in which, and the conditions subject to which, a 2005 Actapplication is to be treated as an application under section 17F for a watersupply or sewerage licence giving a particular authorisation or particularauthorisations;
the time at which an application is to be treated as having been made;
the processing of an application by the Authority.
Provision under subsection (2)(a) may require a 2005 Act application thatis forwarded to the Authority—
to contain, or to be accompanied by, such information or information ofsuch description as is specified by the regulations;
to be accompanied by such documents or documents of such descriptions asare specified by the regulations;
to be accompanied by a fee, or a fee of a description, specified by theregulations.
In this section and section 17FB—
* “the 2005 Act” means the Water Services etc. (Scotland) Act 2005;
* “2005 Act application” means an application under paragraph 1 of Schedule 2 to the 2005 Act.
FBApplications forwarded to the Water Industry Commission forScotland
If the conditions in subsection (2) are satisfied, the Authority must—
forward to the Commission a copy of an application under section 17F forthe grant of a water supply licence or sewerage licence, and
send to the Commission such information and such fee as appear to theAuthority to be required in order that the application may be treated by theCommission as a 2005 Act application for the grant of—
a water services licence under section 6 of the 2005 Act, or
a sewerage services licence under section 6 of the 2005 Act, as the casemay be.
The conditions are that—
the Authority is requested to do so by the applicant;
the application under section 17F appears to the Authority to be anapplication that would be treated by the Commission as a 2005 Act applicationfor the grant of—
a water services licence under section 6 of the 2005 Act, or
a sewerage services licence under section 6 of the 2005 Act, as the casemay be;
the applicant has given the Authority—
such information as is mentioned in subsection (1)(b), and
a means of sending to the Commission such fee as is mentioned insubsection (1)(b).
The Authority must—
forward a copy of the application, and
send such information and fee as are mentioned in subsection (1)(b),
before the end of the agreed period for an application of that description.
In this section—

* “the agreed period”, in relation to an application under section 17F of a particular description, means the period agreed between the Authority and the Commission as the period applying to an application of that description for the purposes of subsection (3);
* “the Commission” means the Water Industry Commission for Scotland.”
Arrangements with the Water Services Regulation Authority
The Water Services etc. (Scotland) Act 2005 is amended as follows.
In Schedule 2 (procedure for granting licences), after paragraph 1 there isinserted—
“Applications forwarded by the Water Services Regulation Authority
1A(1)The Scottish Ministers may by order make provision about—

treating an application under section 17F of the 1991 Act for the grant ofa water supply licence giving a retail authorisation or a restricted retailauthorisation as being also an application under paragraph 1 for the grant ofa water services licence;

treating an application under section 17F of the 1991 Act for the grant ofa sewerage licence giving a retail authorisation as being also an applicationunder paragraph 1 for the grant of a sewerage services licence.
The order may in particular make provision about—

the circumstances in which, and the conditions subject to which, anapplication under section 17F of the 1991 Act is to be treated as anapplication under paragraph 1 for a water services licence or a sewerageservices licence;
the time at which an application is to be treated as having been made;
the processing of an application by the Commission.
Provision under sub-paragraph (2)(a) may require an application undersection 17F of the 1991 Act that is forwarded to the Commission—
to include, or be accompanied by, information prescribed by the order;
to be accompanied by a fee, or a fee of a description, prescribed by theorder.
In this paragraph and paragraph 1B “the 1991 Act” means the Water IndustryAct 1991.
Applications forwarded to the Water Services Regulation Authority
1B(1)If the conditions in sub-paragraph (2) are satisfied, the Commissionmust—
forward to the Authority a copy of an application under paragraph 1 for thegrant of a water services licence or sewerage services licence;

send to the Authority such information, documents and fee as appear to theCommission to be required in order that the application may be treated by theAuthority as an application under section 17F of the 1991 Act for the grantof—
a water supply licence giving a retail authorisation or a restricted retailauthorisation or both, or
a sewerage licence giving a retail authorisation,
as the case may be.
The conditions are that—
the Commission is requested to do so by the applicant;
the application under paragraph 1 appears to the Commission to be anapplication that would be treated by the Authority as an application undersection 17F of the 1991 Act for the grant of—
a water supply licence giving a retail authorisation or a restricted retailauthorisation or both, or
a sewerage licence giving a retail authorisation,
as the case may be;
the applicant has given the Commission—
such information and documents as are mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(b),and
a means of sending to the Authority such fee as is mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(b).
The Commission must—
forward a copy of the application, and
send such information, documents and fee as are mentioned in sub-paragraph(1)(b),
before the end of the agreed period for an application of that description.
In this paragraph—

* “the agreed period”, in relation to an application under paragraph 1 of a particular description, means the period agreed between the Commission and the Authority as the period applying to an application of that description for the purposes of sub-paragraph (3);
* “the Authority” means the Water Services Regulation Authority.”
In section 6 (grant of water services and sewerage services licences)—
in subsection (1), for “paragraphs 1 and 2” there is substituted“paragraphs 1, 1A and 2”;
in subsection (3), for “paragraphs 1 and 2” there is substituted“paragraphs 1, 1A and 2”.
In section 34 (orders and regulations), in subsection (3)(c), after “or(4)” there is inserted “, 1A(1)”.
CHAPTER 2Water and sewerage undertakers
Arrangements between relevant undertakers
Bulk supply of water by water undertakers
For sections 40 and 40A of the Water Industry Act 1991 (agreements for thebulk supply of water etc) there is substituted—
“40Bulk supplies
This section applies where—
a qualifying person requests a water undertaker to provide a supply ofwater in bulk to the qualifying person, or
a water undertaker proposes such an arrangement;
and references in this section to the supplier are references to the waterundertaker who is to provide the supply of water.
In this section “qualifying person” means—
a water undertaker;
a person who has made an application for an appointment or variation undersection 8 which has not been determined.
On the application of the qualifying person or the supplier, the Authoritymay—

if it appears to the Authority that it is necessary or expedient for thepurposes of securing the efficient use of water resources, or the efficientsupply of water, that the supplier should give a supply of water in bulk tothe qualifying person, and
if the Authority is satisfied that the supplier and qualifying personcannot reach agreement within a reasonable time,
by order require the supplier to give and the qualifying person to take asupply of water in bulk for such period and on such terms and conditions asmay be specified in the order.

Before making an order under subsection (3), the Authority must consult theappropriate agency, in particular about whether the proposed supply of waterwould secure an efficient use of water resources, taking into account theeffect on the environment of the proposed supply.
Subject to subsection (6), an order under subsection (3) has effect as anagreement between the supplier and the qualifying person.

If the Authority makes an order under subsection (3) that affects a personwho is a qualifying person by virtue of subsection (2)(b), the Authority mustframe the order so that it does not have effect until—
the person becomes a water undertaker for the area specified in the order,or
the person becomes a water undertaker for an area that includes the areaspecified in the order (in the case of a water undertaker applying for avariation).
Neither the CMA nor the Authority may exercise, in respect of an agreementfor the supply of water in bulk by a water undertaker to a qualifying person,the powers conferred by—
section 32 of the Competition Act 1998 (directions in relation toagreements);
section 35(2) of that Act (interim directions).
Subsection (7)(b) does not apply to the exercise of powers in respect ofconduct—
which is connected with an agreement for the supply of water in bulk by awater undertaker to a qualifying person, and

in respect of which section 35(1) of the Competition Act 1998 appliesbecause of an investigation under section 25 of that Act relating to asuspected infringement of the Chapter 2 prohibition imposed by section 18(1)of that Act.
In exercising its functions under this section, the Authority must haveregard to the desirability of—
facilitating effective competition within the water supply industry;
the supplier’s recovering the expenses of complying with its obligations byvirtue of this section and securing a reasonable return on its capital;
the supplier’s being able to meet its existing obligations, and likelyfuture obligations, to supply water without having to incur unreasonableexpenditure in carrying out works;
not putting at risk the ability of the supplier to meet its existingobligations, or likely future obligations, to supply water.

In this section and section 40A “the appropriate agency”, in relation to adetermination whether to make an order under subsection (3) or section 40A(1)which would result in, or which would vary or terminate, a bulk supplyagreement, means—
the Environment Agency, in a case where all parties to the bulk supplyagreement are or would be—
a water undertaker whose area is wholly in England, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a waterundertaker;
the NRBW, in a case where all parties to the bulk supply agreement are orwould be—
a water undertaker whose area is wholly in Wales, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a waterundertaker;
both the Environment Agency and the NRBW, in any other case.
In this section and sections 40A to 40J “bulk supply agreement” means anagreement with one or more water undertakers for the supply of water in bulkand includes—
an order under subsection (3) which is deemed to be an agreement by virtueof subsection (5), and
any agreement which has been varied by order under section 40A(1).
AVariation and termination of bulk supply agreements
On the application of any party to a bulk supply agreement, the Authoritymay—

if it appears to the Authority that it is necessary or expedient for thepurpose of securing the efficient use of water resources, or the efficientsupply of water, that the bulk supply agreement should be varied orterminated, and
if the Authority is satisfied that variation or termination cannot beachieved by agreement within a reasonable time,
by order vary or terminate the bulk supply agreement.

Before making an order under subsection (1), the Authority must consult theappropriate agency, in particular about whether the proposed variation ortermination of the bulk supply agreement would secure an efficient use ofwater resources, taking into account the effect on the environment of what isproposed.
If an order under subsection (1) is made in relation to a bulk supplyagreement, the agreement—
has effect subject to the provision made by the order, or
ceases to have effect (as the case may be).
An order under subsection (1) may require any party to the agreement to paycompensation to any other party.
Neither the CMA nor the Authority may exercise, in respect of an agreementto vary or terminate a bulk supply agreement, the powers conferred by—
section 32 of the Competition Act 1998 (directions in relation toagreements);
section 35(2) of that Act (interim directions).
Subsection (5)(b) does not apply to the exercise of powers in respect ofconduct—
which is connected with an agreement to vary or terminate a bulk supplyagreement, and

in respect of which section 35(1) of the Competition Act 1998 appliesbecause of an investigation under section 25 of that Act relating to asuspected infringement of the Chapter 2 prohibition imposed by section 18(1)of that Act.

In exercising its functions under this section, the Authority must haveregard to the expenses incurred by the supplier in complying with itsobligations under the bulk supply agreement in question and to thedesirability of—
facilitating effective competition within the water supply industry;
the supplier’s recovering the expenses of complying with its obligations byvirtue of this section and securing a reasonable return on its capital;
the supplier’s being able to meet its existing obligations, and likelyfuture obligations, to supply water without having to incur unreasonableexpenditure in carrying out works;
not putting at risk the ability of the supplier to meet its existingobligations, or likely future obligations, to supply water.
In this section and sections 40B to 40J—
* “qualifying person” has the meaning given by section 40;
* “supplier”, in relation to a bulk supply agreement, means any water undertaker which is required by the agreement to provide a bulk supply of water.
BCodes in respect of bulk supply agreements
The Authority may issue one or more codes in respect of bulk supplyagreements.
A code may make provision about—
procedures in connection with making a bulk supply agreement;
procedures in connection with varying or terminating a bulk supplyagreement;
procedures to be followed by the Authority in determining whether to makean order under section 40(3) or 40A(1);
the terms and conditions of a bulk supply agreement, including terms as tothe duration of such an agreement;
principles for determining the terms and conditions that should or shouldnot be incorporated into a bulk supply agreement;
the steps to be taken by the Authority in determining whether a person iscomplying with a code.
A code must include provision requiring persons proposing to make, vary orterminate a bulk supply agreement to consult the appropriate agency.

If the Authority considers that a water undertaker is not acting asrequired by a code, the Authority may give the undertaker a direction to do,or not to do, a particular thing specified in the direction.
The Authority may not give a direction under subsection (4) requiring aperson to enter into, vary or terminate an agreement.
It is the duty of a water undertaker to comply with a direction undersubsection (4), and this duty is enforceable by the Authority under section18.
A code may make different provision for different persons or differentdescriptions of person.
The Authority may from time to time revise a code issued under this sectionand issue a revised code.
A revised code may include provision for applying any of its revisions tobulk supply agreements made before the revised code comes into force.

In this section “the appropriate agency”, in relation to a bulk supplyagreement or proposed bulk supply agreement, means the body that would beconsulted by the Authority under section 40(4) or 40A(2) if an order undersection 40(3) or 40A(1) were being considered in relation to the agreement orproposed agreement.
CCodes under section 40B: procedure
Before issuing a code under section 40B, the Authority must—
prepare a draft of the proposed code under section 40B;
consult the appropriate agency;
consult such other persons about the proposed code as it considersappropriate.
The Authority must specify the period (“the consultation period”) withinwhich persons may make representations about the proposed code.
Before a code under section 40B prepared by the Authority is issued, theMinister may direct the Authority—
not to issue the code, or
to issue the code with specified modifications.
Subsection (3) is subject to subsections (6) and (7).
In subsection (3) “the Minister” means—
the Secretary of State, so far as a code prepared by the Authority relatesto bulk supply agreements to which all parties are—
a water undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in England, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a waterundertaker;
the Welsh Ministers, so far as a code prepared by the Authority relates tobulk supply agreements to which all parties are—
a water undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in Wales, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a waterundertaker;
the Secretary of State and the Welsh Ministers acting jointly, so far as acode prepared by the Authority relates to bulk supply agreements to which—
a person falling within paragraph (a)(i) or (ii) is party, and
a person falling within paragraph (b)(i) or (ii) is party.

If the power under subsection (3) is exercised to give a direction inrespect of such bulk supply agreements as are referred to in paragraph (a),(b) or (c) of subsection (5), it may not be exercised again in respect of suchbulk supply agreements as are referred to in that paragraph.

If the power under subsection (3) to give a direction in respect of suchbulk supply agreements as are referred to in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) ofsubsection (5) is not exercised on the first occasion on which it may be soexercised, it may not be exercised in respect of such bulk supply agreementsas are referred to in that paragraph on a later occasion.

A direction under subsection (3) must be given within the period of 28 daysbeginning with the day after the end of the consultation period, and a codeprepared by the Authority in relation to which a direction may be given maynot be issued before that period of 28 days has expired.
In this section “the appropriate agency” means—
the Environment Agency, so far as a proposed code relates to bulk supplyagreements to which all parties are persons mentioned in section 40(10)(a)(i)or (ii);
the NRBW, so far as a proposed code relates to bulk supply agreements towhich all parties are persons mentioned in section 40(10)(b)(i) or (ii);
both the Environment Agency and the NRBW, in any other case.
This section is subject to section 40D.
DCodes under section 40B: minor or urgent revisions
This section applies if the Authority proposes to issue a revised codeunder section 40B and, in the view of the Authority, the revision or each ofthe revisions proposed to be made is—
a revision for which consultation is unnecessary, or
a revision that it is necessary or desirable to make without delay.
Section 40C does not apply to the proposed revised code.
Once the Authority has issued the revised code, it must give notice as soonas reasonably practicable of—
the issuing of the revised code, and
as regards each revision contained in it, whether in the view of theAuthority the revision falls within paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (1).
Notice under subsection (3) is to be given to such persons as the Authorityconsiders appropriate.

Unless the Authority gives notice that a revision in a revised code is inthe view of the Authority a revision falling within subsection (1)(a), therevision ceases to have effect at the end of the period of six monthsbeginning with the day after that on which the revised code is issued.
ERules about charges for the supply of water in bulk
The Authority may issue rules about charges that may be imposed by a waterundertaker under a bulk supply agreement.
The rules may in particular make provision about—
what types of charge may be imposed;
the amount or the maximum amount, or a method for determining the amount ormaximum amount, of any type of charge;
principles for determining what types of charge may or may not be imposed;
principles for determining the amount of any charge that may be imposed;
publication of the charges that may be imposed.

If the Authority considers that a water undertaker is not acting asrequired by rules under this section, the Authority may give the undertaker adirection to do, or not to do, a particular thing specified in the direction.
It is the duty of a water undertaker to comply with a direction undersubsection (3), and this duty is enforceable by the Authority under section18.
The rules may—
make different provision for different water undertakers or differentdescriptions of water undertaker;
make different provision for different purposes;
make provision subject to exceptions.
The Authority may from time to time revise rules issued under this sectionand issue revised rules.
The Authority must issue revised rules if—
guidance is issued under section 40I, and
the Authority, having regard to that guidance, considers that it isappropriate to revise the rules.
Revised rules may include provision for applying any of their revisions tobulk supply agreements made before the revised rules come into effect.
FRules under section 40E: provision about the reduction of charges
Rules under section 40E may provide for the reduction of charges payablefor a supply of water under a bulk supply agreement where conditions specifiedby the rules are satisfied.
Rules made by virtue of subsection (1) may in particular—
specify conditions that affect any party to a bulk supply agreement;
require that steps be taken for the purpose of reducing or managing waterconsumption;
specify conditions about reducing charges payable by a person who—
is not party to the agreement, and
takes or proposes to take such steps as satisfy or would satisfy acondition falling within paragraph (b).

The rules may provide that, where a charge falls to be reduced inaccordance with rules made by virtue of subsection (1), the water undertakerto which the charges are payable must give notice of that reduction to theAuthority.
Rules made by virtue of subsection (3) may—
make provision as to the content of the notice;
specify the period within which an undertaker is to give notice to theAuthority.
Provision under subsection (4)(a) may in particular require the notice tospecify—
the provision of the rules that brings about the reduction in the charge;
the amount of the charge, with and without the reduction;
the period for which the reduction has effect.
GRules under section 40E: procedure
Before issuing rules under section 40E, the Authority must—
prepare a draft of the proposed rules, and
consult such persons about the proposed rules as it thinks appropriate.
The Authority must specify the period (“the consultation period”) withinwhich persons may make representations about the proposed rules.
The Authority must have regard to guidance issued under section 40I inmaking rules under section 40E.
Before rules under section 40E prepared by the Authority are issued, theMinister may direct the Authority not to issue the rules.
In subsection (4) “the Minister” means—
the Secretary of State, so far as rules prepared by the Authority relate tobulk supply agreements to which all parties are—
a water undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in England, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a waterundertaker;
the Welsh Ministers, so far as rules prepared by the Authority relate tobulk supply agreements to which all parties are—
a water undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in Wales, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a waterundertaker;
the Secretary of State and the Welsh Ministers acting jointly, so far asrules prepared by the Authority relate to bulk supply agreements to which—
a person falling within paragraph (a)(i) or (ii) is party, and
a person falling within paragraph (b)(i) or (ii) is party.

A direction under subsection (4) must be given within the period of 28 daysbeginning with the day after the end of the consultation period, and rules maynot be issued before that period of 28 days has expired.
This section is subject to section 40H.
HRules under section 40E: minor or urgent revisions
This section applies if the Authority proposes to issue revised rules undersection 40E and, in the view of the Authority, the revision or each of therevisions proposed to be made is—
a revision for which consultation is unnecessary, or
a revision that it is necessary or desirable to make without delay.
Section 40G does not apply to the proposed revised rules.
Before issuing the revised rules, the Authority must give notice to theMinister of its intention to issue revised rules.
Before the revised rules are issued, the Minister may direct the Authoritynot to issue the revised rules.

A direction under subsection (4) must be given within the period of 14 daysbeginning with the day after the day on which notice is given under subsection(3), and the Authority may not issue the revised rules in question before—
that period of 14 days expires, or
the Minister notifies the Authority that no direction under subsection (4)will be given in relation to the revised rules,
whichever is the sooner.
Once the Authority has issued the revised rules, it must give notice assoon as reasonably practicable of—
the issuing of the revised rules, and
as regards each revision contained in them, whether in the view of theAuthority the revision falls within paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (1).
Notice under subsection (6) is to be given to such persons as the Authorityconsiders appropriate.

Unless the Authority gives notice that a revision in revised rules is inthe view of the Authority a revision falling within subsection (1)(a), therevision ceases to have effect at the end of the period of six monthsbeginning with the day after that on which the revised rules are issued.
In this section “the Minister” has the meaning given by section 40G.
IRules under section 40E: guidance
The Minister may issue guidance as to the content of rules under section40E.
Before issuing the guidance, the Minister must—
prepare a draft of the proposed guidance;
consult the relevant persons about the draft.
The relevant persons are—
the Secretary of State;
the Welsh Ministers;
such other persons as the Minister thinks appropriate.
The Minister may from time to time revise the guidance and issue revisedguidance.
Subsections (2) and (3) apply to revised guidance as they apply to theoriginal guidance.
The Minister must arrange for the publication of guidance issued under thissection.
In this section “the Minister” means—
the Secretary of State, in relation to bulk supply agreements to which allparties are—
a water undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in England, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a waterundertaker;
the Welsh Ministers, in relation to bulk supply agreements to which allparties are—
a water undertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in Wales, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a waterundertaker;
the Secretary of State and the Welsh Ministers acting jointly, in relationto bulk supply agreements to which—
a person falling within paragraph (a)(i) or (ii) is party, and
a person falling within paragraph (b)(i) or (ii) is party.
JDuty to provide information about bulk supplies
A supplier under a bulk supply agreement must provide such information asthe appropriate agency may request in relation to water supplied under theagreement.
The requirement in subsection (1) is enforceable by the Authority undersection 18.

In subsection (1) “the appropriate agency” means the body that would beconsulted by the Authority under section 40A(2) if the agreement were to bevaried or terminated by an order under section 40A(1).”
In sections 40A to 40J of the Water Industry Act 1991 (as substituted bysubsection (1))—
a reference to a bulk supply agreement includes a reference to an old bulksupply agreement, and
a reference to a supplier, in relation to a bulk supply agreement, is to beconstrued accordingly.
For these purposes, an old bulk supply agreement is a bulk supply agreementwithin the meaning of section 40A, as that section had effect before beingsubstituted under subsection (1).
Main connections into sewerage systems
For section 110A of the Water Industry Act 1991 (new connections withpublic sewers) there is substituted—
“110AMain connections
This section applies where—
a qualifying person requests a sewerage undertaker to permit a mainconnection into the established undertaker’s sewerage system for the benefitof the qualifying person, or
a sewerage undertaker proposes such an arrangement;
and references in this section to the established undertaker are references tothe sewerage undertaker who is to permit the main connection.
In this section “qualifying person” means—
a sewerage undertaker, or
a person who has made an application for an appointment or variation undersection 8 which has not been determined.
On the application of the qualifying person or the established undertaker,the Authority may—
if it appears to the Authority that it is necessary or expedient for thepurposes of this Part that the established undertaker should permit a mainconnection into its sewerage system, and
if the Authority is satisfied that the established undertaker andqualifying person cannot reach agreement,
by order require the established undertaker to permit the connection for suchperiod and on such terms and conditions as may be specified in the order.
Before making an order under subsection (3), the Authority must consult theappropriate agency.
Subject to subsection (6), an order under subsection (3) has effect as anagreement between the established undertaker and the qualifying person.

If the Authority makes an order under subsection (3) on the application ofa person who is a qualifying person by virtue of subsection (2)(b), theAuthority must frame the order so that it does not have effect until—
the person becomes a sewerage undertaker for the area specified in theorder, or
the person becomes a sewerage undertaker for an area that includes the areaspecified in the order (in the case of a sewerage undertaker applying for avariation).

Neither the CMA nor the Authority may exercise, in respect of an agreementwith a sewerage undertaker for it to permit a main connection into itssewerage system for the benefit of a qualifying person, the powers conferredby—
section 32 of the Competition Act 1998 (directions in relation toagreements);
section 35(2) of that Act (interim directions).
Subsection (7)(b) does not apply to the exercise of powers in respect ofconduct—
which is connected with such agreement as is mentioned in subsection (7),and

in respect of which section 35(1) of the Competition Act 1998 appliesbecause of an investigation under section 25 of that Act relating to asuspected infringement of the Chapter 2 prohibition imposed by section 18(1)of that Act.
In exercising its functions under this section, the Authority must haveregard to the desirability of—
facilitating effective competition within the sewerage services industry;
the established undertaker’s recovering the expenses of complying with itsobligations by virtue of this section and securing a reasonable return on itscapital;

the established undertaker’s being able to meet its existing obligations,and likely future obligations, to provide sewerage services without having toincur unreasonable expenditure in carrying out works;
not putting at risk the ability of the established undertaker to meet itsexisting obligations, or likely future obligations, to provide such services.

In this section and section 110B “the appropriate agency”, in relation toa determination whether to make an order under subsection (3) or section110B(1) which would result in, or which would vary or terminate, a mainconnection agreement, means—
the Environment Agency, in a case where all parties to the main connectionagreement are or would be—
a sewerage undertaker whose area is wholly in England, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a sewerageundertaker;
the NRBW, in a case where all parties to the main connection agreement areor would be—
a sewerage undertaker whose area is wholly in Wales, or
a person who would, if the person’s application for an appointment orvariation is determined in accordance with the application, be such a sewerageundertaker;
both the Environment Agency and the NRBW, in any other case.
In this section and sections 110B to 110J—
* “main connection” means—
a connection between a sewer or disposal main and a sewer or disposal main, or
a connection which allows a sewer or disposal main to discharge directly intoa sewage disposal works;
* “main connection agreement” means an agreement with one or more sewerage undertakers for that undertaker or each of them to permit a main connection into its sewerage system and includes—
an order under subsection (3) which is deemed to be an agreement by virtue ofsubsection (5), and
any agreement which has been varied by order under section 110B(1).
BVariation and termination of main connection agreements
On the application of any party to a main connection agreement, theAuthority may—
if it appears to the Authority that it is necessary or expedient for thepurpose of this Part that the main connection agreement should be varied orterminated, and
if the Authority is satisfied that variation or termination cannot beachieved by agreement,
by order vary or terminate the main connection agreement.
Before making an order under subsection (1), the Authority must consult theappropriate agency.
If an order under subsection (1) is made in relation to a main connectionagreement, the agreement—
has effect subject to the provision made by the order, or
ceases to have effect (as the case may be).
An order under subsection (1) may require any party to the agreement to paycompensation to any other party.
Neither the CMA nor the Authority may exercise, in respect of an agreementto vary or terminate a main connection agreement, the powers conferred by—
section 32 of the Competition Act 1998 (directions in relation toagreements);
section 35(2) of that Act (interim directions).
Subsection (5)(b) does not apply to the exercise of powers in respect ofconduct—
which is connected with an agreement to vary or terminate a main connectionagreement, and

in respect of which section 35(1) of the Competition Act 1998 appliesbecause of an investigation under section 25 of that Act relating to asuspected infringement of the Chapter 2 prohibition imposed by section 18(1)of that Act.

In exercising its functions under this section, the Authority must haveregard to the expenses incurred by the established undertaker in complyingwith its obligations under the main connection agreement in question and tothe desirability of—
facilitating effective competition within the sewerage services industry;
the established undertaker’s recovering the expenses of complying with itsobligations by virtue of this section and securing a reasonable return on itscapital;

the established undertaker’s being able to meet its existing obligations,and likely future obligations, to provide sewerage services without having toincur unreasonable expenditure in carrying out works;
not putting at risk the ability of the established undertaker to meet itsexisting obligations, or likely future obligations, to provide such services.

In this section and sections 110C to 110J “established undertaker”, inrelation to a sewerage agreement, means the sewerage undertaker which isrequired by the agreement to permit a main connection into its seweragesystem.
CCodes in respect of main connection agreements
The Authority may issue one or more codes in respect of main connectionagreements.
A code may make provision about—
procedures in connection with making an agreement to permit a mainconnection into a sewerage undertaker’s sewerage system;
procedures in connection with varying or terminating a main connectionagreement;
procedures to be followed by the Authority in determining whether to makean order under section 110A(3) or 110B(1);
the terms and conditions of a main connection agreement, including terms asto the duration of such an agreement;
principles for determining the terms and conditions that should or shouldnot be incorporated into a main connection agreement;
the steps to be taken by the Authority in determining whether a person iscomplying with the code.

If the Authority considers that a sewerage undertaker is not acting asrequired by a code, the Authority may give the undertaker a direction to do,or not to do, a particular thing specified in the direction.
The Authority may not give a direction under subsection (3) requiring aperson to enter into, vary or terminate an agreement.
It is the duty of a sewerage undertaker to comply with a direction undersubsection (3), and this duty is enforceable by the Authority under section18.
A code may make different provision for different persons or differentdescriptions of person.
The Authority may from time to time revise a code issued under this sectionand issue a revised code.
A revised code may include provision for applying any of its revisions tomain connection agreements made before the revised code comes into force.
DCodes under section 110C: procedure
Before issuing a code under section 110C, the Authority must—
prepare a draft of the proposed code under section 110C, and
consult such persons about the proposed code as it considers appropriate.
The Authority must specify the period (“the consultation period”) withinwhich a person may make representations about the proposed code.
Before a code under section 110C prepared by the Authority is issued, theMinister may direct the Authority—
not to issue the code, or
to issue the code with specified modifications.
Subsection (3) is subject to subsections (6) and (7).
In subsection (3) “the Minister” means—
the Secretary of State, so far as a code prepared by the Authority relatesto main connection agreements under which—
the main connection into a sewerage system, or
each such connection,
is or would be a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerageundertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in England for the benefit ofanother such undertaker;
the Welsh Ministers, so far as a code prepared by the Authority relates tomain connection agreements under which—
the main connection into a sewerage system, or
each such connection,
is or would be a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerageundertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in Wales for the benefit of anothersuch undertaker;

the Secretary of State and the Welsh Ministers acting jointly, so far as acode prepared by the Authority relates to main connection agreements underwhich one main connection into a sewerage system is or would be—
a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerage undertaker whosearea is wholly or mainly in England for the benefit of a sewerage undertakerwhose area is wholly or mainly in Wales, or
a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerage undertaker whosearea is wholly or mainly in Wales for the benefit of a sewerage undertakerwhose area is wholly or mainly in England.

If the power under subsection (3) is exercised to give a direction inrespect of such main connection agreements as are referred to in paragraph(a), (b) or (c) of subsection (5), it may not be exercised again in respect ofsuch main connection agreements as are referred to in that paragraph.

If the power under subsection (3) to give a direction in respect of suchmain connection agreements as are referred to in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) ofsubsection (5) is not exercised on the first occasion on which it may be soexercised, it may not be exercised in respect of such main connectionagreements as are referred to in that paragraph on a later occasion.

A direction under subsection (3) must be given within the period of 28 daysbeginning with the day after the end of the consultation period, and a code inrelation to which a direction may be given may not be issued before thatperiod of 28 days has expired.
ECodes under section 110C: minor or urgent revisions
This section applies if the Authority propose to issue a revised code undersection 110C and, in the view of the Authority, the revision or each of therevisions proposed to be made is—
a revision for which consultation is unnecessary, or
a revision that it is necessary or desirable to make without delay.
Section 110D does not apply to the revised code.
Once the Authority has issued the revised code, it must give notice as soonas reasonably practicable of—
the issuing of the revised code, and
as regards each revision contained in it, whether in the view of theAuthority the revision falls within paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (1).
Notice under subsection (3) is to be given to such persons as the Authorityconsiders appropriate.

Unless the Authority gives notice that a revision in a revised code is inthe view of the Authority a revision falling within subsection (1)(a), therevision ceases to have effect at the end of the period of six monthsbeginning with the day after that on which the revised code is issued.
FRules about charges for permitting main connections
The Authority may issue rules about charges that may be imposed by asewerage undertaker under a main connection agreement.
The rules may in particular make provision about—
what types of charge may be imposed;
the amount or the maximum amount, or a method for determining the amount ormaximum amount, of any type of charge;
principles for determining what types of charge may or may not be imposed;
principles for determining the amount of any charge that may be imposed;
publication of the charges that may be imposed.

If the Authority considers that a sewerage undertaker is not acting asrequired by rules under this section, the Authority may give the undertaker adirection to do, or not to do, a particular thing specified in the direction.
It is the duty of a sewerage undertaker to comply with a direction undersubsection (3), and this duty is enforceable by the Authority under section18.
The rules may—
make different provision for different sewerage undertakers or differentdescriptions of sewerage undertaker;
make different provision for different purposes;
make provision subject to exceptions.
The Authority may from time to time revise rules issued under this sectionand issue revised rules.
The Authority must issue revised rules if—
guidance is issued under section 110J, and
the Authority, having regard to that guidance, considers that it isappropriate to revise the rules.
Revised rules may include provision for applying any of the revisions tomain connection agreements made before the revised rules come into effect.
GRules under section 110F: provision about the reduction of charges
Rules under section 110F may provide for the reduction of charges payableunder a main connection agreement where conditions specified by the rules aresatisfied.
Rules made by virtue of subsection (1) may in particular—
specify conditions by reference to any party to a main connectionagreement;
require that steps be taken for the purpose of reducing the cost to asewerage undertaker of permitting a main connection into its sewerage system;
specify conditions about reducing charges payable by a person who—
is not party to the agreement, and
takes or proposes to take such steps as satisfy or would satisfy acondition falling within paragraph (b).

The rules may provide that, where a charge falls to be reduced inaccordance with rules made by virtue of subsection (1), the sewerageundertaker to which the charges are payable must give notice of that reductionto the Authority.
Rules made by virtue of subsection (3) may—
make provision as to the content of the notice;
specify the period within which an undertaker is to give notice to theAuthority.
Provision under subsection (4)(a) may in particular require the notice tospecify—
the provision of the rules that brings about the reduction in the charge;
the amount of the charge, with and without the reduction;
the period for which the reduction has effect.
HRules under section 110F: procedure
Before issuing rules under section 110F, the Authority must—
prepare a draft of the proposed rules, and
consult such persons about the proposed rules as it thinks appropriate.
The Authority must specify the period (“the consultation period”) withinwhich persons may make representations about the proposed rules.
The Authority must have regard to guidance issued under section 110J inmaking rules under section 110F.
Before rules under section 110F prepared by the Authority are issued, theMinister may direct the Authority not to issue the rules.
In subsection (4) “the Minister” means—
the Secretary of State, so far as rules prepared by the Authority relate tomain connection agreements under which—
the main connection into a sewerage system, or
each such connection,
is or would be a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerageundertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in England for the benefit ofanother such undertaker;
the Welsh Ministers, so far as rules prepared by the Authority relate tomain connection agreements under which—
the main connection into a sewerage system, or
each such connection,
is or would be a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerageundertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in Wales for the benefit of anothersuch undertaker;

the Secretary of State and the Welsh Ministers acting jointly, so far asrules prepared by the Authority relate to main connection agreements underwhich one main connection into a sewerage system is or would be—
a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerage undertaker whosearea is wholly or mainly in England for the benefit of a sewerage undertakerwhose area is wholly or mainly in Wales, or
a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerage undertaker whosearea is wholly or mainly in Wales for the benefit of a sewerage undertakerwhose area is wholly or mainly in England.

A direction under subsection (4) must be given within the period of 28 daysbeginning with the day after the end of the consultation period, and rules maynot be issued before that period of 28 days has expired.
This section is subject to section 110I.
IRules under section 110F: minor or urgent revisions
This section applies if the Authority proposes to issue revised rules undersection 110F and, in the view of the Authority, the revision or each of therevisions proposed to be made is—
a revision for which consultation is unnecessary, or
a revision that it is necessary or desirable to make without delay.
Section 110H does not apply to the proposed revised rules.
Before issuing the revised rules, the Authority must give notice to theMinister of its intention to issue revised rules.
Before the revised rules are issued, the Minister may direct the Authoritynot to issue the revised rules.

A direction under subsection (4) must be given within the period of 14 daysbeginning with the day after the day on which notice is given under subsection(3), and the Authority may not issue the revised rules in question before—
that period of 14 days expires, or
the Minister notifies the Authority that no direction under subsection (4)will be given in relation to the revised rules,
whichever is the sooner.
Once the Authority has issued the revised rules, it must give notice assoon as reasonably practicable of—
the issuing of the revised rules, and
as regards each revision contained in them, whether in the view of theAuthority the revision falls within paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (1).
Notice under subsection (6) is to be given to such persons as the Authorityconsiders appropriate.

Unless the Authority gives notice that a revision in revised rules is inthe view of the Authority a revision falling within subsection (1)(a), therevision ceases to have effect at the end of the period of six monthsbeginning with the day after that on which the revised rules are issued.
In this section “the Minister” has the meaning given by section 110H.
JRules under section 110F: guidance
The Minister may issue guidance as to the content of rules under section110F.
Before issuing the guidance, the Minister must—
prepare a draft of the proposed guidance;
consult the relevant persons about the draft.
The relevant persons are—
the Welsh Ministers;
the Secretary of State;
such other persons as the Minister thinks appropriate.
The Minister may from time to time revise the guidance and issue revisedguidance.
Subsections (2) and (3) apply to revised guidance as they apply to theoriginal guidance.
The Minister must arrange for the publication of guidance issued under thissection.
In this section “the Minister” means—
the Secretary of State, in relation to main connection agreements underwhich—
any main connection into a sewerage system, or
each such connection,
is or would be a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerageundertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in England for the benefit ofanother such undertaker;
the Welsh Ministers, in relation to main connection agreements under which—
any main connection into a sewerage system, or
each such connection,
is or would be a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerageundertaker whose area is wholly or mainly in Wales for the benefit of anothersuch undertaker;
the Secretary of State and the Welsh Ministers acting jointly, in relationto main connection agreements under which one main connection into a seweragesystem is or would be—
a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerage undertaker whosearea is wholly or mainly in England for the benefit of a sewerage undertakerwhose area is wholly or mainly in Wales, or
a main connection into the sewerage system of a sewerage undertaker whosearea is wholly or mainly in Wales for the benefit of a sewerage undertakerwhose area is wholly or mainly in England.”
In sections 110B to 110J of the Water Industry Act 1991 (as substituted bysubsection (1))—
a reference to a main connection agreement includes a reference to an oldmain connection agreement, and
a reference to an established undertaker, in relation to a main connectionagreement, is to be construed accordingly.
For the purposes of subsection (2)—

“old main connection agreement” means an agreement made before the cominginto force of subsection (1) that is an agreement with one or more sewerageundertakers for that undertaker or each of them to permit a main connectioninto its sewerage system, and includes an order under old section 110A whichis deemed to be an agreement by virtue of old section 110A(5);
references to old section 110A are references to section 110A, as thatsection had effect before being substituted under subsection (1).
Agreements to adopt infrastructure
Agreements by water undertakers to adopt infrastructure
The Water Industry Act 1991 is amended as follows.
In section 51A (agreements to adopt a water main or service pipe at afuture date)—

in subsection (3) (application to make an agreement under section 51A), forthe words from “make an application” to the end there is substituted “requesta water undertaker to make an agreement under this section.”;
subsections (4) to (8) are repealed;
after subsection (9) there is inserted—
“(9A)The reference in subsection (9) to an agreement made under this sectionincludes a reference to—
an order under section 51B which is deemed to be an agreement by virtue ofsection 51B(5), and
an agreement which has been varied by order under section 51C(1).”
For section 51B (appeals with respect to adoption) and section 51C(financial conditions of compliance) there is substituted—
“51BAdoption at a future date: orders by Authority
This section applies where a person constructing or proposing to constructa water main or service pipe makes a request to a water undertaker undersection 51A(3).
The person or the water undertaker may apply to the Authority for an orderunder subsection (4) if the person and the water undertaker have not made suchagreement as was requested by the person.
The Authority may, on the application of the person or the waterundertaker, make an order under subsection (4) if the Authority is satisfiedthat—
it is appropriate for work proposed to be done by a person other than thewater undertaker to be so done, and
the person and the water undertaker cannot reach agreement within areasonable time.
The Authority may by order—
require the water undertaker to give such undertakings as to the vesting ofthe water main or service pipe in the undertaker as the Authority may specify,and
impose such terms and conditions as regards taking the benefit of theundertakings as the Authority may specify.
An order under subsection (4) has effect as an agreement under section 51Abetween the person and the water undertaker.

The Authority may not, by order under subsection (4), require a waterundertaker to vest in itself a water main or service pipe as regards whichthere is a contravention of any of the requirements of section 74 that areprescribed for the purposes of this subsection.
The Authority may not make an order under subsection (4) with respect to awater main or service pipe that is situated within the area of another waterundertaker, until either—
that other undertaker has consented in writing to the making of the order,or
the Minister, on an application made to the Minister, has disappliedparagraph (a), either unconditionally or subject to such conditions as theMinister thinks fit.
“The Minister” means—
the Secretary of State, as regards the consent of a water undertaker whosearea is wholly or mainly in England;
the Welsh Ministers, as regards the consent of a water undertaker whosearea is wholly or mainly in Wales.
Neither the CMA nor the Authority may exercise, in respect of an agreementfor the vesting of a water main or service pipe in a water undertaker at afuture date, the powers conferred by—
section 32 of the Competition Act 1998 (directions in relation toagreements);
section 35(2) of that Act (interim directions).
Subsection (9)(b) does not apply to the exercise of powers in respect ofconduct—
which is connected with an agreement for the vesting of a water main orservice pipe at a future date, and

in respect of which section 35(1) of the Competition Act 1998 appliesbecause of an investigation under section 25 of that Act relating to asuspected infringement of the Chapter 2 prohibition imposed by section 18(1)of that Act.
In exercising its functions under this section, the Authority must haveregard to the desirability of—
facilitating effective competition within the water supply industry;
the recovery by the water undertaker of the expenses of complying with itsobligations by virtue of this section and securing a reasonable return on itscapital;
the ability of the water undertaker to meet its existing obligations, andlikely future obligations, to supply water without having to incurunreasonable expenditure in carrying out works;
not putting at risk the ability of the water undertaker to meet itsexisting obligations, or likely future obligations, to supply water.
CVariation and termination of section 51A agreements
On the application of a party to a section 51A agreement to vary (orterminate) the agreement, the Authority may—
if it appears to the Authority that it is necessary or expedient that thesection 51A agreement should be varied (or terminated),
if the Authority is satisfied, in the case of an application to vary theagreement, that it is appropriate for work proposed to be done by a personother than the water undertaker to be so done, and
if the Authority is satisfied that variation (or termination) cannot beachieved by agreement within a reasonable time,
by order vary (or terminate) the section 51A agreement.
If an order under subsection (1) is made in relation to a section 51Aagreement, the agreement—
has effect subject to the provision made by the order, or
ceases to have effect, as the case may be.
An order under subsection (1) may require any party to the agreement to paycompensation to any other party.
Neither the CMA nor the Authority may exercise, in respect of an agreementto vary or terminate a section 51A agreement, the powers conferred by—
section 32 of the Competition Act 1998 (directions in relation toagreements);
section 35(2) of that Act (interim directions).
Subsection (4)(b) does not apply to the exercise of powers in respect ofconduct—
which is connected with an agreement to vary or terminate a section 51Aagreement, and

in respect of which section 35(1) of the Competition Act 1998 appliesbecause of an investigation under section 25 of that Act relating to asuspected infringement of the Chapter 2 prohibition imposed by section 18(1)of that Act.

In exercising its functions under this section, the Authority must haveregard to the expenses incurred by the water undertaker in complying with itsobligations under the section 51A agreement in question and to thedesirability of—
facilitating effective competition within the water supply industry;
the recovery by the water undertaker of the expenses of complying with itsobligations by virtue of this section and securing a reasonable return on itscapital;
the ability of the water undertaker to meet its existing obligations, andlikely future obligations, to supply water without having to incurunreasonable expenditure in carrying out works;
not putting at risk the ability of the water undertaker to meet itsexisting obligations, or likely future obligations, to supply water.

In this section and sections 51CA to 51CG “section 51A agreement” means anagreement with a water undertaker for the vesting of a water main or servicepipe in a water undertaker at a future date and includes—
an order under section 51B which is deemed to be an agreement by virtue ofsection 51B(5), and
any agreement which has been varied by order under subsection (1).
CACodes in respect of section 51A agreements
The Authority must issue a code in respect of section 51A agreements.
The code may make provision about—
procedures in connection with making an agreement under section 51A;
procedures in connection with varying or terminating a section 51Aagreement;
procedures to be followed by the Authority in determining whether to makean order under section 51B(4) or 51C(1);
the circumstances in which it is, or is not, appropriate for work to bedone by a person other than a water undertaker;
the terms and conditions of a section 51A agreement;
principles for determining the terms and conditions that should or shouldnot be incorporated into a section 51A agreement;
the steps to be taken by the Authority in determining whether a person iscomplying with the code.
Provision under subsection (2)(c) may in particular require the Authorityto consult—
the Chief Inspector of Drinking Water;
the Chief Inspector of Drinking Water for Wales if there is one.
Provision under subsection (2)(d) may include in particular provision aboutcircumstances relating to—
the nature of the work;
the kind of premises supplied or to be supplied.
Provision under subsection (2)(e) may include in particular provision aboutterms and conditions as regards—
constructing associated infrastructure;
vesting associated infrastructure in a water undertaker;
constructing water mains so as to meet additional supply requirements;
connecting new water mains or service pipes to the existing supply systemof a water undertaker;
complying with requirements of the kind referred to in section 47(2);
the duration of a section 51A agreement.

If the Authority considers that a water undertaker is not acting asrequired by the code, the Authority may give the undertaker a direction to do,or not to do, a particular thing specified in the direction.
The Authority may not give a direction under subsection (6) requiring aperson to enter into, vary or terminate an agreement.
It is the duty of a water undertaker to comply with a direction undersubsection (6), and this duty is enforceable by the Authority under section18.
The code may make different provision for different persons or descriptionsof person.
The Authority must from time to time review the code and, if appropriate,issue a revised code.
A revised code may include provision for applying any of its revisions tosection 51A agreements made before the revised code comes into force.
CBCodes under section 51CA: procedure
Before issuing a code under section 51CA, the Authority must—
prepare a draft of the proposed code under section 51CA, and
consult the relevant persons about the proposed code.
The relevant persons are—
the Chief Inspector of Drinking Water;
the Chief Inspector of Drinking Water for Wales if there is one;
such other persons as the Authority considers appropriate.
The Authority must specify the period (“the consultation period”) withinwhich a person may make representations about the proposed code.
Before a code under section 51CA prepared by the Authority is issued, theMinister may direct the Authority—
not to issue the code, or
to issue the code with specified modifications.
Subsection (4) is subject to subsections (7) and (8).
In subsection (4) “the Minister” means—
the Secretary of State, so far as the code relates to section 51Aagreements for the vesting of water mains or service pipes in waterundertakers whose areas are wholly or mainly in England;
the Welsh Ministers, so far as the code relates to section 51A agreementsfor the vesting of water mains or service pipes in water undertakers whoseareas are wholly or mainly in Wales.

A direction under subsection (4) must be given within the period of 28 daysbeginning with the day after the end of the consultation period, and a code inrelation to which a direction may be given may not be issued before thatperiod of 28 days has expired.

CDRules about charges in connection with a section 51A agreement
The Authority may issue rules about charges that may be imposed by a waterundertaker under a section 51A agreement.
The rules may in particular make provision about—
what types of charge may be imposed;
the amount or the maximum amount, or a method for determining the amount ormaximum amount, of any type of charge;
principles for determining what types of charge may or may not be imposed;
principles for determining the amount of any charge that may be imposed;
publication of the charges that may be imposed.

The rules may require a water undertaker, upon declaring a water main orservice pipe to be vested in the undertaker in accordance with a section 51Aagreement, to pay to the other party to the agreement an amount (which may benil) determined in accordance with the rules.
Rules made by virtue of subsection (3) may, in particular, provide for thedetermination to take into account—
revenue that might be derived from the water main or service pipe inquestion;
costs that might have been incurred in providing such a water main orservice pipe.
The rules may also make provision as to—
the amount of security that may be required by a water undertaker for thepurposes of any charges imposed by the water undertaker under a section 51Aagreement;
the type of security that may be required;
the payment of interest on a sum deposited with a water undertaker by wayof security.

If the Authority considers that a water undertaker is not acting asrequired by rules under this section, the Authority may give the undertaker adirection to do, or not to do, a particular thing specified in the direction.
It is the duty of a water undertaker to comply with a direction undersubsection (6), and this duty is enforceable by the Authority under section18.
The rules may make different provision for different water undertakers ordescriptions of undertaker.
The Authority may from time to time revise rules issued under this sectionand issue revised rules.

guidance is issued under section 51CG, and
the Authority, having regard to that guidance, considers that it isappropriate to revise the rules.

Agreements by sewerage undertakers to adopt infrastructure

After section 105 there is inserted—
“105ZAAdoption at a future date: orders by Authority
This section applies where a person mentioned in section 104(1)(a) or (b)makes a request to a sewerage undertaker under section 104(2).

The Authority may, on the application of the person or the sewerageundertaker, make an order under subsection (4) if the Authority is satisfiedthat—
where the person is such person as is mentioned in section 104(1)(a), it isappropriate for work proposed to be done by a person other than the sewerageundertaker to be so done, and
the person and the sewerage undertaker cannot reach agreement within areasonable time.
The Authority may by order—

require the sewerage undertaker to give such undertakings as to the vestingof the sewer, such part of the drain as constitutes the lateral drain or theworks in the undertaker as the Authority may specify, and
impose such terms and conditions as regards taking the benefit of theundertakings as the Authority may specify.
An order under subsection (4) has effect as an agreement under section 104between the person and the sewerage undertaker.
The Authority may not make an order under subsection (4) with respect to—
a sewer, drain or sewage disposal works situated in the area of anotherundertaker, or
a drain which is intended to communicate with a sewer which—
is so situated, or
is vested in another sewerage undertaker,
until one of the conditions mentioned in subsection (7) is satisfied.
The conditions are that—
the other sewerage undertaker has consented in writing to the making of theorder, or
the Minister, on an application made to the Minister, has disappliedparagraph (a), either unconditionally or subject to such conditions as theMinister thinks fit.
“The Minister” means—
the Secretary of State, as regards the consent of a sewerage undertakerwhose area is wholly or mainly in England;
the Welsh Ministers, as regards the consent of a sewerage undertaker whosearea is wholly or mainly in Wales.

Neither the CMA nor the Authority may exercise, in respect of an agreementfor the vesting of a sewer, drain or sewage disposal works in a sewerageundertaker at a future date or on a future event, the powers conferred by—
section 32 of the Competition Act 1998 (directions in relation toagreements);
section 35(2) of that Act (interim directions).
Subsection (9)(b) does not apply to the exercise of powers in respect ofconduct—
which is connected with an agreement for the vesting of a sewer, drain orsewage disposal works in a sewerage undertaker at a future date or on a futureevent, and

in respect of which section 35(1) of the Competition Act 1998 appliesbecause of an investigation under section 25 of that Act relating to asuspected infringement of the Chapter 2 prohibition imposed by section 18(1)of that Act.
In exercising its functions under this section, the Authority must haveregard to the desirability of—
facilitating effective competition within the sewerage services industry;
the recovery by the sewerage undertaker of the expenses of complying withits obligations by virtue of this section and securing a reasonable return onits capital;

the ability of the sewerage undertaker to meet its existing obligations,and likely future obligations, to provide sewerage services without having toincur unreasonable expenditure in carrying out works;
not putting at risk the ability of the sewerage undertaker to meet itsexisting obligations, or likely future obligations, to provide sewerageservices.
ZBVariation and termination of section 104 agreements
On the application of a party to a section 104 agreement to vary (orterminate) the agreement, the Authority may—
if it appears to the Authority that it is necessary or expedient that thesection 104 agreement should be varied (or terminated),

if the Authority is satisfied, in the case of an application to vary theagreement involving such person as is mentioned in section 104(1)(a), that itis appropriate for work proposed to be done by a person other than thesewerage undertaker to be so done, and
if the Authority is satisfied that variation (or termination) cannot beachieved by agreement within a reasonable time,
by order vary (or terminate) the section 104 agreement.
If an order under subsection (1) is made in relation to a section 104agreement, the agreement—
has effect subject to the provision made by the order, or
ceases to have effect, as the case may be.
An order under subsection (1) may require any party to the agreement to paycompensation to any other party.
Neither the CMA nor the Authority may exercise, in respect of an agreementto vary or terminate a section 104 agreement, the powers conferred by—

facilitating effective competition within the sewerage services industry;
the recovery by the sewerage undertaker of the expenses of complying withits obligations by virtue of this section and securing a reasonable return onits capital;

the ability of the sewerage undertaker to meet its existing obligations,and likely future obligations, to provide sewerage services without having toincur unreasonable expenditure in carrying out works;
